<!-- Extra parameters --> | header = Satanic Verses controversy | header_align = <!-- left/right/center --> | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = <!-- left/right/center --> | footer_background = | background colour = }} '''''The Satanic Verses'' controversy''', also known as the '''Rushdie Affair''', was the heated and frequently violent reaction of [[Muslims]] to the publication of [[Salman Rushdie]]'s novel ''[[The Satanic Verses]]'', which was first published in the [[United Kingdom]] in 1988 and inspired in part by the life of [[Muhammad]]. Many Muslims accused Rushdie of [[blasphemy]] or unbelief and in 1989 the Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] of Iran issued a [[fatwa]] ordering Muslims to kill Rushdie. Numerous killings, attempted killings, and bombings resulted from violent Muslims over the novel.<ref>Jessica Jacobson. ''Islam in transition: religion and identity among British Pakistani youth''. 1998, page 34</ref>
The [[Iranian government]] backed the fatwa against Rushdie until 1998, when the succeeding government of Iranian President [[Mohammad Khatami]] said it no longer supported the killing of Rushdie.<ref name="HttpquerynytimescomgstfullpagehtmlresFEDFFAACAE">{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F02E5DF1439F936A1575AC0A96E958260 | work=The New York Times | first=Barbara | last=Crossette | title=Iran Drops Rushdie Death Threat, And Britain Renews Teheran Ties | date=25 September 1998 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224152053/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F02E5DF1439F936A1575AC0A96E958260 | archivedate=24 February 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, the fatwa remains in place.<ref name=fatwacont/>
The issue was said to have divided "Muslims from Westerners along the fault line of culture,"<ref name="Pipes, 1990, p.133">Pipes, 1990, p.133</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+:&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false From Fatwa to Jihad: The Rushdie Affair and Its Aftermath By Kenan Malik] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509201749/https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+%3A&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA |date=9 May 2016 }}, introduction, no page numbers</ref> and to have pitted a core Western value of [[Freedom of speech|freedom of expression]]—that no one "should be killed, or face a serious threat of being killed, for what they say or write"<ref>{{cite news |author=Timothy Garton Ash |url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,,2109613,00.html |title=No ifs and no buts |work=The Guardian |accessdate=27 January 2012 |location=London |date=22 June 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219121900/http://books.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,,2109613,00.html |archivedate=19 December 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>—against the view of many Muslims—that no one should be free to "insult and malign Muslims" by disparaging the "honour of the Prophet".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2007/06/2008525123146597321.html |title=Pakistan blasts Rushdie honour |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=27 January 2012}}</ref> English writer [[Hanif Kureishi]] called the fatwa "one of the most significant events in postwar literary history."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/14/looking-at-salman-rushdies-satanic-verses?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Looking back at Salman Rushdie's The Satanic Verses|newspaper=The Guardian|date=14 September 2012|accessdate=14 September 2012|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008194257/http://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/14/looking-at-salman-rushdies-satanic-verses?INTCMP=SRCH|archivedate=8 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Background== Even before the publication of ''The Satanic Verses'', the books of Salman Rushdie had stoked controversy. Rushdie saw his role as a writer "as including the function of antagonist to the state".<ref>Rushdie, Salman, ''Jaguar Smile''; New York: Viking, 1987, p.50</ref> His second book ''[[Midnight's Children]]'' angered [[Indira Gandhi]] because it seemed to suggest "that Mrs. Gandhi was responsible for the death of [[Feroze Gandhi|her husband]] through neglect".<ref name="Netton">{{Cite book|title=Text and Trauma: An East-West Primer |author=Ian Richard Netton|year=1996|publisher=Routledge Curzon|location=Richmond, UK|isbn=0-7007-0325-X}}</ref> His 1983 ''[[roman à clef]]'' ''[[Shame (Rushdie novel)|Shame]]'' "took an aim on Pakistan, its political characters, its culture and its religion... [It covered] a central episode in Pakistan's internal life, which portrays as a family squabble between Iskander Harappa ([[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]]) and his successor and executioner Raza Hyder ([[Zia ul-Haq]])... 'The Virgin Ironpants'... has been identified as [[Benazir Bhutto]], a Prime Minister of Pakistan".<ref name="Netton"/>
Positions Rushdie took as a committed leftist prior to the publication of his book were the source of some controversy. He defended many of those who would later attack him during the controversy. Rushdie forcefully denounced the [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah]]'s government and supported the [[Iranian Revolution|Islamic Revolution of Iran]], at least in its early stages. He condemned the [[1986 Bombing of Libya|US bombing raid on Tripoli in 1986]] but found himself threatened by [[Libya]]'s leader [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]] three years later.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.236</ref> He wrote a book bitterly critical of [[US foreign policy]] in general and its [[Sandinista#Sandinistas vs. Contras|war in Nicaragua]] in particular, for example calling the [[United States government]], "the bandit posing as sheriff".<ref>Rushdie, ''Jaguar Smile'', Viking, 1987</ref> After the Ayatollah's fatwa however, he was accused by Iranian government of being "an inferior [[CIA]] agent".<ref>"The book's author is in England but the real supporter is the United States" – Interior Minister Mohtashemi (IRNA 17 February 1989) "An Iranian government statement called Rushdie "an inferior CIA agent" and referred to the book as a "provocative American deed"". (IRNA 14 February 1989) (Pipes, 1990, p.129)</ref> A few years earlier, an official jury appointed by a ministry of the Iranian Islamic government had bestowed an award on the [[Persian language|Persian]] translation of Rushdie's book ''Shame'', which up until then was the only time a government had awarded Rushdie's work a prize.{{citation needed|date = February 2017}}
==Controversial elements of ''The Satanic Verses''== {{Further|Satanic Verses}} "[V]ehement protest against Rushdie's book" began with the title itself. The title refers to a legend of the Islamic Prophet [[Mohammad]], when a few verses were supposedly spoken by him as part of the [[Qur'an]], and then withdrawn on the grounds that [[the devil]] had sent them to deceive Mohammad into thinking they came from [[Allah|God]]. These "[[Satanic Verses]]" are found in verses eighteen to twenty-two in surah An-Najim of the Qur'an,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://quran.com/53/18-22 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306203937/http://quran.com/53/18-22 |archivedate=6 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and by accounts from Tabari, but is seldom mentioned in the first biography of Mohammad by [[Ibn Ishaq]]. The verses also appear in other accounts of the prophet's life. They permitted prayer to three pre-Islamic [[Quraysh (tribe)|Meccan]] goddesses: [[Al-lāt]], [[Uzza]], and [[Manāt]]—a violation of [[monotheism]].<ref name="Erickson"/> The utterance and withdrawal of the so-called Satanic Verses forms an important sub-plot in the novel, which recounts several episodes in the life of Muhammad. The phrase Arab historians and later Muslims used to describe the incident of the withdrawn verses was not "Satanic verses", but the ''gharaniq'' verses; the phrase 'Satanic verses' was unknown to Muslims, and was coined by Western academics specialising in the [[Orientalism|study of Middle Eastern culture]]. The story itself is not found in the six Sahih of the sunni or the shiite sources, so much so that Muraghi, in his commentary, says: "These traditions are undoubtedly a fabrication of the heretics and foreign hands, and have not been found in any of the authentic books" ...<ref name="Muraghi">{{Cite book|title=Tafsir Muraghi, vol. 17, pg. 130, under the abovementioned verse.|author=Al Muraghi}}</ref><ref name="qharanic">{{cite web|title=What is the Myth of Gharaniq or 'The Satanic Verses'?|author=Ayatullah al-'Uzma al-Hajj ash-Shaykh Nasir Makarim Shirazi|url=http://www.al-islam.org/180-questions-about-islam-vol-2-various-issues-makarim-shirazi/43-what-myth-gharaniq-or-'-satanic|publisher=The Islamic Education Board of the World Federation of Khoja Shia Ithna-Asheri Muslim Communities|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701110337/http://www.al-islam.org/180-questions-about-islam-vol-2-various-issues-makarim-shirazi/43-what-myth-gharaniq-or-%E2%80%98-satanic|archivedate=1 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to Daniel Pipes,<ref>[[Daniel Pipes]]</ref> when attention was drawn to a book with this title, "Muslims found [it] incredibly sacrilegious", and took it to imply that the book's author claimed that verses of the Qur'an were "the work of the Devil".<ref name="Erickson">{{Cite book|title=Islam and Postcolonial Narrative|author=John D. Erickson|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|year=1998|isbn=0-511-00769-8}}</ref>
According to McRoy (2007), other controversial elements included the use of the name [[Mahound]], said to be a derogatory term for Muhammad used by the English during the [[Crusades]]; the use of the term Jahilia, denoting the 'time of ignorance' before Islam, for the holy city of [[Mecca]]; the use of the name of the [[Angels in Islam|Angel]] [[Jibril|Gibreel]] (Gabriel) for a film star, of the name of [[Saladin]], the great Muslim hero of the Crusades, for a devil, and the name of [[Aisha|Ayesha]] the wife of Muhammad for a fanatical Indian girl who leads her village on a fatal pilgrimage. Moreover, the brothel of the city of [[Jahilia]] was staffed by prostitutes with the same names as [[Muhammad's marriages|Muhammad's wives]],<ref name="Pipes65">Pipes, 1990, p. 65</ref> who are viewed by Muslims as '[[Mother of the Believers|the Mothers of all Believers]]'.<ref name="McRoy">{{cite web|title=Why Muslims feel angry about the Rushdie knighthood|date=1 July 2007|author=Anthony McRoy|url=http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/news/?NewsID=875 |publisher=Religious Intelligence |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215055220/http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/news/?NewsID=875 |archivedate=15 February 2009}}</ref>
Other issues many Muslims have found offensive include [[Islamic views on Abraham|Abraham]] being called a "bastard" for casting [[Hagar (Bible)|Hagar]] and [[Ishmael]] in the desert;<ref name = Bombay>{{Cite journal|author1=Michael M. J. Fischer |author2=Mehdi Abedi |title = Bombay Talkies, the Word and the World: Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses|journal = [[Cultural Anthropology (journal)|Cultural Anthropology]]|volume = 5|issue = 2|pages = 124–132|date=May 1990|doi=10.1525/can.1990.5.2.02a00010}}</ref> and a character named Salman the Persian who serves as one of the Prophet's scribes, an apparent reference to the story, controversial among Muslims, of a Meccan convert by the name of [[Abdullah ibn Saad|Ibn Abi Sarh]], who left Islam after the Prophet failed to notice small changes he had made in the dictation of the Qur'an.<ref>[http://www.answering-islam.org/Quran/Sources/sarh.html Ibn Abi Sarh] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217113334/http://www.answering-islam.org/Quran/Sources/sarh.html |date=17 February 2014 }}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=September 2012}}
[[Daniel Pipes]] identified other more general issues in the book likely to have angered pious Muslims: A complaint in the book by one of Mahound's companions: "rules about every damn thing, if a man farts let him turn his face to the wind, a rule about which hand to use for the purpose of cleaning one's behind ...", which was said to mix up "Islamic law with its opposite and with the author's whimsy";<ref name="Pipes65"/> the prophet of Rushdie's novel, as he lies dying, being visited in a dream by the Goddess [[Al-lāt]], on the grounds that this suggested either that she exists or that the prophet thought she did; the angel Gibreel's vision of the Supreme Being in another dream as "not abstract in the least. He saw, sitting on the bed, a man of about the same age as himself", balding, wearing glasses and "seeming to suffer from dandruff".<ref name="Pipes67">Pipes, 1990, p. 67</ref> A complaint by one of the characters about communal violence in India: "Fact is, religious faith, which encodes the highest aspirations of human race, is now, in our country, the servant of lowest instincts, and God is the creature of evil".<ref name="Pipes67"/>
''[[Guardian newspaper|The Guardian]]'' newspaper published on 14 September 2012 a series of recollections of various British people involved in the controversy. [[Lisa Appignanesi]], ex-president of English [[English PEN|PEN]], observed "Intransigence is never so great as when it feels it has a god on its side." One of the lawyers involved, [[Geoffrey Robertson]] [[Queen's Counsel|QC]], rehearsed the arguments and replies made when 13 Muslim [[barristers]] had lodged a formal indictment against Rushdie for the crime of [[blasphemous libel]]: it was said that God was described in the book as "the Destroyer of Man", yet he is described as such in the [[Old Testament]] and the [[Book of Revelation]], especially of men who are unbelievers or enemies of the Jews; that the book contained criticisms of the prophet Abraham, yet the Islamic, Christian and Jewish traditions themselves see Abraham as not without fault and deserving of criticism; that Rushdie referred to Mohammed as "Mahound", a conjurer, a magician and a false prophet, yet these remarks are made by a drunken apostate, a character with whom neither reader nor author has any sympathy; that the book insults the wives of the Prophet by having whores use their names, yet the wives are explicitly said to be chaste and the adoption of their names by whores is to symbolise the corruption of the city then being described (perhaps symbolising Mecca in its pre-Islamic state); that the book vilified the companions of the Prophet, calling them "bums from Persia" and "clowns", yet the character saying this is a hack poet hired to write propaganda against the Prophet and does not reflect the author's beliefs; that the book criticised Islam for having too many rules and seeking to control every aspect of life, yet while characters in the book do make such remarks these cannot constitute blasphemy since they do not vilify God or the Prophet.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/14/looking-at-salman-rushdies-satanic-verses | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Salman Rushdie (Author),Fiction (Books genre),Publishing (Books),Books,Culture,Blake Morrison,Hari Kunzru (author),Ian McEwan (Author),Peter Carey (Author),Hanif Kureishi (Author),Fay Weldon (Author),Religion (Books genre),Religion (News),Michael Holroyd | date=14 September 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170121121224/https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/14/looking-at-salman-rushdies-satanic-verses | archivedate=21 January 2017 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Early reaction== Before the publication of ''The Satanic Verses'', the publisher received "warnings from the publisher's editorial consultant" that the book might be controversial.<ref name="Netton"/> Later, Rushdie would reflect upon the time that the book was about to be published. Speaking to an interviewer, he said, "I expected a few [[mullah]]s would be offended, call me names, and then I could defend myself in public... I honestly never expected anything like this".<ref name="Netton"/>
''The Satanic Verses'' was published by [[Viking Penguin]] on 26 September 1988 in the UK, and on 22 February 1989 in the US.<ref name="Netton"/> Upon its publication the book garnered considerable critical acclaim in the United Kingdom. On 8 November 1988, the work received the [[1988 Whitbread Awards|Whitbread Award]] for novel of the year,<ref name="Netton"/> worth £20,000.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.42</ref> According to one observer, "almost all the British book reviewers" were unaware of the book's connection to Islam because Rushdie has used the name Mahound instead of Muhammad for his chapter on Islam.<ref name="Pipes65"/>
===Muslim response and book bannings===
In Islamic communities, the novel became instantly controversial, because of what some Muslims considered [[blasphemy|blasphemous]] references. Rushdie was accused of misusing [[freedom of speech]].<ref>[[Abdolkarim Soroush]]'s speech in the US, November 2002, Farsi Text, it has been published in [http://www.drsoroush.com/PDF/F-CMB-13820100-Freedom_of_Speech.pdf Aftab monthly magazine in April 2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613060231/http://www.drsoroush.com/PDF/F-CMB-13820100-Freedom_of_Speech.pdf |date=13 June 2013 }}</ref> By October 1988, letters and phone calls arrived at Viking Penguin from Muslims, angry with the book and demanding that it be withdrawn.<ref name="Netton"/> Before the end of the month, the import of the book was [[Banned books|banned]] in India, although possession of the book is not a criminal offence.<ref name="Netton"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-01-25/india/30662344_1_import-ban-book-satanic-verses | work=The Times of India | title=Reading 'Satanic Verses' legal | date=25 January 2012}}</ref>
In November 1988, it was also banned in [[Bangladesh]], [[Sudan]], and South Africa. By December 1988, it was also banned in [[Sri Lanka]].<ref name="Netton"/>
In Britain on 2 December 1988, 7,000 Muslims in the town of [[Bolton]] staged the first ever demonstration against ''The Satanic Verses''. After the Friday prayers, a certain section of the congregation marched from the Zakariyya Jame Masjid to the town centre and then burned the book. The organisers claimed "It was a peaceful protest, and we burned the book to try and attract public attention".<ref>Robin Lustig, Martin Bailey, Simon de Bruxelles and Ian Mather The Guardian newspapers story of events around the Book {{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1989/feb/19/race.world |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008235518/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/1989/feb/19/race.world |archivedate=8 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[City of Bradford]] gained international attention in January 1989 when some of its members organised a public book-burning of ''The Satanic Verses'', evoking as the journalist [[Robert Winder]] recalled "images of medieval (not to mention Nazi) intolerance".<ref name=winder>Winder, Robert. ''Bloody Foreigners: The Story of Immigration to Britain''. Abacus, London: 2013: p. 414</ref>
In February, when the US edition was published, a new round of reviews and criticism began. March 1989 saw it banned in Kenya, Thailand, Tanzania, Indonesia, and Singapore.<ref name="Netton"/> The last nation to ban the book was Venezuela, in June 1989.<ref name="Netton"/>
====Attacks====
In the United States, the [[FBI]] was notified of 78 threats to bookstores in early March 1989, thought to be a small proportion of the total number of threats. [[B. Dalton]] bookstore chain received 30 threats in less than three hours. Bombings of book stores included two in [[Berkeley, California]]. In New York, the office of a community newspaper, ''[[The Riverdale Press]]'', was all but destroyed by firebombs following the publication of an editorial defending the right to read the novel and criticising the bookstores that pulled it from their shelves.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pitt|first1=David E.|title=Office of Weekly Paper in Riverdale Is Firebombed|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/nyregion/office-of-weekly-paper-in-riverdale-is-firebombed.html|accessdate=9 April 2015|work=The New York Times|date=1 March 1989|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525103953/http://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/01/nyregion/office-of-weekly-paper-in-riverdale-is-firebombed.html|archivedate=25 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> But the United Kingdom was the country where violence against bookstores occurred most often and persisted the longest. Two large bookstores in [[Charing Cross]] Road, London, ([[Collets Bookshop|Collets]] and [[Dillons Booksellers|Dillons]]) were bombed on 9 April. In May, explosions went off in the town of [[High Wycombe]] and again in London, on [[Kings Road]]. Other bombings included one at a large London department store ([[Liberty & Co.|Liberty's]]), in connection with the Penguin Bookshop inside the store, and at the Penguin store in [[York]]. Unexploded devices were found at Penguin stores in [[Guildford]], [[Nottingham]], and [[Peterborough]].{{citation needed|date=September 2012}}
In the United States, it was unavailable in about one-third of bookstores. In many others that carried the book, it was kept under the counter.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.169-171</ref>
=={{anchor|Fatwa}}Fatwa by Ayatollah Khomeini== After the book was first published in the United Kingdom, in September 1988, there were protests by Muslims mainly in India and the UK. When it was published in the United States, six months later (in February 1989), it received renewed attention, and the protests took a more deadly form.
On 12 February 1989, a 10,000-strong protest against Rushdie and the book took place in Islamabad, Pakistan. Six protesters were killed in an attack on the American Cultural Center, and an [[American Express]] office was ransacked.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9jK9LnwmaAgC&dq=Iran+Rushdie+%22diplomatic+relations%22+%227+March%22&q=Islamabad#v=snippet&q=Islamabad&f=false ''The Rushdie File'', p. 67] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120231224/https://books.google.com/books?id=9jK9LnwmaAgC&dq=Iran+Rushdie+%22diplomatic+relations%22+%227+March%22&q=Islamabad |date=20 January 2016 }}</ref>
On 14 February, [[Ayatollah]] [[Ruhollah Khomeini]], the [[Supreme Leader of Iran]] and one of the most prominent [[Shi'a]] Muslim leaders, issued a [[fatwa]] calling for the death of Rushdie and his publishers. This created a major international incident that persisted for decades.
Broadcast on Iranian radio, the judgement read:
{{quote|[[Inna Lillahi wa inna ilaihi raji'un|We are from Allah and to Allah we shall return]]. I am informing all brave Muslims of the world that the author of The Satanic Verses, a text written, edited, and published against Islam, the Prophet of Islam, and the Qur'an, along with all the editors and publishers aware of its contents, are condemned to death. I call on all valiant Muslims wherever they may be in the world to kill them without delay, so that no one will dare insult the sacred beliefs of Muslims henceforth. And whoever is killed in this cause will be a martyr, Allah Willing. Meanwhile if someone has access to the author of the book but is incapable of carrying out the execution, he should inform the people so that [Rushdie] is punished for his actions.|Rouhollah al-Mousavi al-Khomeini.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Ayatollah sentences author to death|publisher=BBC|date=14 February 1989|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/14/newsid_2541000/2541149.stm|accessdate=22 January 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217213012/http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/14/newsid_2541000/2541149.stm|archivedate=17 February 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>}}
Khomeini did not give a legal reasoning for his judgement. It is thought to be based on the ninth chapter of the Qur'an, called [[At-Tawba]], verse 61: "Some of them hurt the prophet by saying, 'He is all ears!' Say, 'It is better for you that he listens to you. He believes in God, and trusts the believers. He is a mercy for those among you who believe.' Those who hurt God's messenger have incurred a painful retribution".<ref name="rel">{{Cite book|title=''The Resilience of Conservative Religion: The Case of Popular, Conservative Protestant Congregations''|author=Joseph Bernard Tamney|publisher=The Press Syndicate of the University of Cambridge| location=Cambridge, UK|year=2002}}</ref> However [[#On Islamic grounds|it was not explained]] how that chapter could support such a judgement.
Over the next few days, Iranian officials offered a bounty of $6 million for killing Rushdie, who was thus forced to live under police protection for the next nine years. On 7 March 1989, the [[United Kingdom-Iran relations|United Kingdom and Iran broke diplomatic relations]] over the Rushdie controversy.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9jK9LnwmaAgC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Iran+Rushdie+%22diplomatic+relations%22+%227+March%22&source=bl&ots=2UfqvkDitf&sig=bHgzrtp4oYQNNGMbq4q6tfON8Es&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r5DgU8P8JMyw7Ab7oIGwBg&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Iran%20Rushdie%20%22diplomatic%20relations%22%20%227%20March%22&f=false Letter from the Private Secretary, 16 March 1989: quoted in ''The Rushdie File, p. 120] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120231224/https://books.google.com/books?id=9jK9LnwmaAgC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Iran+Rushdie+%22diplomatic+relations%22+%227+March%22&source=bl&ots=2UfqvkDitf&sig=bHgzrtp4oYQNNGMbq4q6tfON8Es&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r5DgU8P8JMyw7Ab7oIGwBg&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBA |date=20 January 2016 }}</ref><ref name="month-rushdies">[http://bostonreview.net/archives/BR14.4/rushdie.html The Month of Rushdies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820235838/http://bostonreview.net/archives/BR14.4/rushdie.html |date=20 August 2016 }}, Eliot Weinberger. ''Boston Review'', March 15, 1989. Retrieved July 29, 2016.</ref>
===Rushdie's apology and reaction===
====Rushdie's apology==== On 18 February, Iran's President [[Ali Khamenei]] (who would later that year succeed Khomeini as Supreme Leader) suggested that if Rushdie "apologises and disowns the book, people may forgive him".<ref name="Moin, 2001 p.284">from Moin, ''Khomeini'', (2001), p.284, (Issued 18 February, Obtained by Baqer Moin from the Archbishop of Canterbury's aides.)]</ref> Following this, Rushdie issued "a carefully worded statement",<ref name="Moin, 2001 p.284"/> saying:
<blockquote>I recognize that Muslims in many parts of the world are genuinely distressed by the publication of my novel. I profoundly regret the distress the publication has occasioned to the sincere followers of Islam. Living as we do in a world of many faiths, this experience has served to remind us that we must all be conscious of the sensibilities of others.<ref name="Moin, 2001 p.284"/></blockquote>
This was relayed to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Tehran "via official channels" before being released to the press.<ref name="Moin, 2001 p.284"/>
====Rejection of Rushdie's apology==== On 19 February 1990, Ayatollah Khomeini's office replied:
{{quote|The imperialist foreign media falsely alleged that the officials of the Islamic Republic have said the sentence of death on the author of ''The Satanic Verses'' will be retracted if he repents. Imam Khomeini has said:
This is denied 100%. Even if Salman Rushdie repents and become the most pious man of all time, it is incumbent on every Muslim to employ everything he has got, his life and wealth, to send him to Hell.}}
The Imam added:
<blockquote>If a non-Muslim becomes aware of Rushdie's whereabouts and has the ability to execute him quicker than Muslims, it is incumbent on Muslims to pay a reward or a fee in return for this action.<ref>Moin, ''Khomeini'', (2001), p.284</ref></blockquote>
McRoy (2007) stated that Khomeini's interpretation of the Islamic law that led him to refuse the apology follows the same line of reasoning as [[Al-Shafi'i]] (9th century jurist), who in his ''Risala'' (Maliki Manual 37.19 ''Crimes Against Islam'') ruled that an "apostate is also killed unless he repents... Whoever abuses the Messenger of God ... is to be executed, and his repentance is not accepted".<ref name="McRoy"/>
===Support for Khomeini's fatwa=== In Britain, the [[Union of Islamic Students' Associations in Europe]] issued a statement offering its services to Khomeini. Despite incitement to murder being illegal in the United Kingdom,<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.182-3</ref> one London property developer told reporters, "If I see him, I will kill him straight away. Take my name and address. One day I will kill him".<ref name="Newsweek, 27 February 1989">''Newsweek'', 27 February 1989</ref>
Other leaders, while supporting the fatwa, claimed that British Muslims were not allowed to carry out the fatwa themselves.{{Why?|date=January 2012}} Prominent amongst these were the [[Muslim Parliament]] and its leader [[Kalim Siddiqui]], and after his death in 1996, his successor, [[Ghayasuddin Siddiqui]]. His support for the fatwa continued, even after the Iranian leadership said it would not pursue the fatwa,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/177987.stm |title=BBC, 23 September 1998 |publisher=BBC News |date=23 September 1998 |accessdate=27 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140926002414/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/177987.stm |archivedate=26 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and re-iterated his support in 2000.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/rushdie-death-warrant-intact-726733.html The Independent, 13 February 2000]</ref>
Meanwhile, in America, the director of the [[Near East Studies Center]] at [[UCLA]], [[George Sabbagh]], told an interviewer that Khomeini was "completely within his rights" to call for Rushdie's death.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/0,9263,7601890227,00.html ''TIME'', 27 February 1989, p.159] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115104320/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/0,9263,7601890227,00.html |date=15 November 2012 }}</ref>
{{Main|Lebanon Hostage Crisis}}
In May 1989 in [[Beirut, Lebanon]], British citizen [[Jackie Mann]] was abducted "in response to Iran's fatwa against Salman Rushdie for the publication of book the Satanic Verses and more specifically, for his refuge and protection in the United Kingdom".<ref>Ranstorp, ''Hizb'allah in Lebanon'', (1997), p.103</ref> He joined several Westerners [[Lebanon Hostage Crisis|held hostage]] there. Two months earlier a photograph of three teachers held hostage was released by [[Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine]] with the message that it "would take revenge against" all institutions and organisations that insulted in one way or another "members of the Prophet Mohammed's family".<ref>"Iran: West to Blame Islam for Forthcoming Terrorism", ''Philadelphia Inquirer'', 24 February 1989, p.5A</ref>
McRoy (2007) claimed that "In Islamic society a blasphemer is held in the same hostile contempt as a pedophile in the West. Just as few if any people in the West mourn the murder of a child molester, few Muslims mourn the killing of a blasphemer".<ref name="McRoy"/>
===Criticism of Khomeini's fatwa=== Khomeini's fatwa was condemned across the Western world by governments on the grounds that it violated the universal human rights of [[free speech]], [[freedom of religion]], and that Khomeini had no right to condemn to death a citizen of another country living in that country.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} The 12 members of the [[European Economic Community]] removed their ambassadors from Tehran for three weeks.<ref name="month-rushdies"/>
====On Islamic grounds==== In addition to criticism of the death sentence on the basis of humans rights, the sentence was also criticised on Islamic grounds. According to [[Bernard Lewis]], a death warrant without trial, [[defence (law)|defence]] and other legal aspects of [[sharia]] violates Islamic jurisprudence. In Islamic [[fiqh]], [[apostasy]] by a mentally sound adult male is indeed a [[capital crime]]. However, fiqh also:
<blockquote> ... lays down procedures according to which a person accused of an offense is to be brought to trial, [[right to confront accusers|confronted with his accuser]], and given the opportunity to defend himself. A judge will then give a verdict and if he finds the accused guilty, pronounce sentence... Even the most rigorous and extreme of the classical jurist only require a Muslim to kill anyone who insults the Prophet in his hearing and in his presence. They say nothing about a hired killing for a reported insult in a distant country.<ref>Bernard Lewis commenting on Rushdie fatwa in ''The Crisis of Islam : Holy War and Unholy Terror'', 2003 by Bernard Lewis, p.141-2</ref></blockquote>
Other Islamic scholars outside Iran took issue with the fact that the sentence was not passed by an Islamic court,<ref name="Newsweek, 27 February 1989"/><ref name="Majalla1989"/> or that it did not limit its "jurisdiction only [to] countries under Islamic law".<ref name="rel"/> Muhammad Hussan ad-Din, a theologian at [[Al-Azhar University]], argued "Blood must not be shed except after a trial [when the accused has been] given a chance to defend himself and repent".<ref name="Newsweek, 27 February 1989"/> Abdallah al-Mushidd, head of Azhar's Fatwā Council stated "We must try the author in a legal fashion as Islam does not accept killing as a legal instrument".<ref name="Majalla1989">"Ab'ad Harb al-Kitab" ''[[The Majalla|Al Majalla]]'', 1 March 1989, quoted in Pipes, 1990, p.93</ref>
The Islamic Jurisprudence Academy in Mecca urged that Rushdie be tried and, if found guilty, be given a chance to repent, (p. 93) and Ayatollah [[Mehdi Rohani]], head of the Shi'i community in Europe and a cousin of Khomeini, criticised Khomeini for 'respect[ing] neither international law nor that of Islam.'<ref>''Le Nouvel Observateur'' 23 February 1989</ref>
There was also criticism of the fatwa issued against Rushdie's publishers. According to Daniel Pipes: "The [[Sharia]] clearly establishes that disseminating false information is not the same as expressing it. "Transmitting blasphemy is not blasphemy" (''naql al-kufr laysa kufr''). In addition, the publishers were not Muslim and so could not be "sentenced under the Islamic laws of apostasy". If there was another legal justification for sentencing them to death, "Khomeini failed to provide" it.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.91</ref>
Iran's response to calls for a trial was to denounce its Islamic proponents as "deceitful". President Khomeini accused them of attempting to use religious law as "a flag under which they can crush revolutionary Islam".<ref>Radio Tehran, 16 March 1989, quoted in Pipes, 1990, p.135</ref>
====Questions of political motivation==== Some speculate that the fatwa (or at least the reaffirmation of the death threat four days later) was issued with motives other than a sense of duty to protect Islam by punishing blasphemy/apostasy. Namely:
*To divide Muslims from the West by "starkly highlight[ing] the conflicting political and intellectual traditions" of the two civilisations.<ref name="Pipes, 1990, p.133" /> Khomeini had often warned Muslims of the dangers of the West – "the agents of imperialism [who] are busy in every corner of the Islamic world drawing our youth away from us with their evil propaganda".<ref>Khomeini, ''Islam and Revolution'' (1980), p.127</ref> He knew from news reports the book was already rousing the anger of Muslims. *To distract the attention of his Iranian countrymen from his capitulation seven months earlier to a truce with [[Iraq]] (20 July 1988) ending the long and bloody [[Iran–Iraq War]] (a truce Iraq would have eagerly given him six years and hundreds of thousands of lives earlier),<ref>Moin, Baqer, ''Khomeini'', (2001), p.267,</ref><ref>''The Gulf War : Its Origins, History and Consequences'' by John Bulloch and Harvey Morris, 1989, (p.xvi)]</ref> and strengthen the revolutionary ardour and morale<ref>''People of the Century'', by CBS News, p.220.</ref> of Iranians worn down by the bloodshed and privation of that war. According to journalist Robin Wright, "as the international furore grew, Khomeini declared that the book had been a 'godsend' that had helped Iran out of a 'naïve foreign policy'".<ref name="rel"/><ref>Wright, Robin ''In the Name of God'', (c1989), p.201</ref> *To win back the interest in and support for the [[Iranian Revolution|Islamic Revolution]] among the 90% of the population of the Muslim world that was [[Sunni]], rather than [[Shia]] like Khomeini. The Iran–Iraq War had also alienated Sunni, who not only were offended by its bloodshed, but tended to favour Iran's Sunni-led opponent, Iraq. At least one observer speculated that Khomeini's choice of the issue of disrespect for the Prophet [[Muhammad]] was a particularly shrewd tactic, as Sunni were inclined to suspect Shia of being more interested in the Imams [[Ali]] and [[Husayn ibn Ali]] than in the Prophet.<ref name="Pipes133-4">Pipes, 1990, 133–4</ref> *To [[Stealing thunder|steal the thunder]] of Khomeini's two least favourite enemy states, [[Saudi Arabia]] and the United States, who were basking in the glory of the [[Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan]]. This withdrawal, seen by many as a great victory of Islamic faith over an atheist superpower, was made possible by billions of dollars in aid to the Afghan mujahideen by those two countries. Khomeini issued the fatwa on 14 February 1989. The next day came the official announcement of the completion of the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, lost in the news cycle of the fatwa.<ref>Kepel, ''Jihad'', (2001), p.135)</ref> *To gain the upper hand from Saudi Arabia in the struggle for international leadership of the Muslim world. Each led rival blocs of international institutions and media networks, and "the Saudi government, it should be remembered, had led the anti-Rushdie campaign for months".<ref name="Pipes133-4"/> Unlike the more conservative Saudi Arabia, however, Iran was ideologically and militantly anti-western and could take a more militant stand outside international law.
====Questions of personal motivation==== Despite claims by Iranian officials that "Rushdie's book did not insult Iran or Iranian leaders" and so they had no selfish personal motivation to attack the book, the book does include an eleven-page sketch of Khomeini's stay in Paris that could well be considered an insult to him. It describes him as having "grown monstrous, lying in the palace forecourt with his mouth yawning open at the gates; as the people march through the gates he swallows them whole". In the words of one observer, "If this is not an insult, Khomeini was far more tolerant than one might suppose",<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.207</ref> [[John Crowley]] has noted that the section of the book depicting the Khomeini-like character was selected to be read publicly by Rushdie in the promotional events leading up to and following the book's release.<ref name="Crowley">{{cite web|last=Crowley |first=John |title=Rushdie and Me |url=http://crowleycrow.livejournal.com/213161.html |publisher=Livejournal |accessdate=15 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120231224/http://crowleycrow.livejournal.com/213161.html |archivedate=20 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In Crowley's opinion, the fatwa was most likely declared because of this section of the novel and its public exposure, rather than the overall parodic treatment of Islam.<ref name="Crowley"/>
===Attempts to revoke the fatwa=== On 24 September 1998, as a precondition to the restoration of [[diplomatic relations]] with Britain, the Iranian government, then headed by moderate [[Muhammad Khatami]], gave a public commitment that it would "neither support nor hinder assassination operations on Rushdie".<ref name="Tomb">{{Cite news|date=8 June 2005|title=Tomb of the unknown assassin reveals mission to kill Rushdie|author=Anthony Loyd|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article531110.ece|work=The Times|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601171205/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article531110.ece|archivedate=1 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/26/newsid_2542000/2542873.stm |publisher=BBC News: On This Day |title=26 December 1990: Iranian leader upholds Rushdie fatwa |accessdate=10 October 2006 |date=26 December 1990 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408091112/http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/26/newsid_2542000/2542873.stm |archivedate=8 April 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, some in Iran have continued to reaffirm the death sentence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/article/1002 |publisher=The Middle East Forum: Promoting American Interests |title=Can Iran Be Trusted? |author=Rubin, Michael |date=1 September 2006 |accessdate=10 October 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061026203104/http://www.meforum.org/article/1002 |archivedate=26 October 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In early 2005, Khomeini's fatwa was reaffirmed by Iran's Supreme Leader, [[Ayatollah Ali Khamenei]], in a message to Muslim pilgrims making the [[Hajj|annual pilgrimage]] to [[Mecca]].<ref name="webster-bbc">{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/printFriendly/0,,1-2-1448279-2,00.html |work=The Times |title=Ayatollah revives the death fatwa on Salman Rushdie |author=Webster, Philip, Ben Hoyle and Ramita Navai |date=20 January 2005 |accessdate=10 October 2006 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016192342/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/printFriendly/0,,1-2-1448279-2,00.html |archivedate=16 October 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Additionally, the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guards]] have declared that the death sentence on him is still valid.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4260599.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Iran adamant over Rushdie fatwa |date=12 February 2005 |accessdate=10 October 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206020617/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4260599.stm |archivedate=6 February 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Iran has rejected requests to withdraw the fatwa on the basis that only the person who issued it may withdraw it,<ref name="webster-bbc"/> with Ruhollah Khomeini having died in 1989.
On 14 February 2006, the [[Islamic Republic News Agency|Iranian state news agency]] reported that the fatwa will remain in place permanently.<ref name=fatwacont>{{Cite news|title=Iran says Rushdie fatwa still stands|publisher=Iran Focus|date=14 February 2006|url=http://www.iranfocus.com/modules/news/article.php?storyid=5768|accessdate=22 January 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20090417232632/http%3A//www.iranfocus.com/en/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D5768|archivedate=17 April 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2007, Salman Rushdie reported that he still receives a "sort of [[Valentine's Day|Valentine]]'s card" from Iran each year on 14 February letting him know the country has not forgotten the vow to kill him. He was also quoted saying, "It's reached the point where it's a piece of rhetoric rather than a real threat".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=2007021501382200.htm&date=2007/02/15/&prd=th& |title=Rushdie's term |accessdate=15 February 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012000434/http://hinduonnet.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=2007021501382200.htm&date=2007%2F02%2F15%2F&prd=th& |archivedate=12 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Social and political fallout== One of the immediate consequences of the fatwa was a worsening of Islamic-Western relations.
===Heightened tension=== Rushdie lamented that the controversy fed the Western stereotype of "the backward, cruel, rigid Muslim, burning books and threatening to kill the blasphemer",<ref>Marzorati, Gerald, "Salman Rushdie: Fiction's Embattled Infidel", ''The New York Times Magazine'', 29 January 1989</ref> while another British writer compared the Ayatollah Khomeini "with a familiar ghost from the past – one of those villainous Muslim clerics, a [[Faqir of Ipi]] or a [[Mohammed Abdullah Hassan|mad Mullah]], who used to be portrayed, larger than life, in popular histories of the British Empire".<ref>Anthony Harly, "Saving Mr. Rushdie?" ''Encounter'', June 1989, p. 74</ref> Media expressions of this included a banner headline in the popular British newspaper the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' referring to Khomeini as "that Mad Mullah".<ref>15 February 1989</ref>
''The Independent'' newspaper worried that Muslim book burning demonstrations were "following the example of the [[Inquisition]] and [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]]'s [[Nazism|National Socialists]]",<ref>''The Independent'', 16 March 1989</ref> and that if Rushdie was killed, "it would be the first burning of a [[Heresy|heretic]] in Europe in two centuries".<ref>League for the Spread of Unpopular Views. West German organization, ''Bund zur Verbreitung unerwunschter Einsichten'' [Hamburg], ''"Der Fall Rushdie und die Feigheit des Westerns,"'' pamphlet, p. 3. quoted in Pipes 1990, p.250</ref> [[Peregrine Worsthorne]] of the ''Sunday Telegraph'' feared that with [[Muslims in Western Europe|Europe's growing Muslim population]], "[[Islamic fundamentalism]] is rapidly growing into a much bigger threat of violence and intolerance than anything emanating from, say, the fascist [[British National Front|National Front]]; and a threat, moreover, infinitely more difficult to contain since it is virtually impossible to monitor, let alone stamp out ...".<ref>Peregrine Worsthorne, "The Blooding of the Literati", ''The Sunday Telegraph'', 19 February 1989</ref>
On the Muslim side, the Iranian government saw the book as part of a British [[wiktionary:Conspiracy|conspiracy]] against Islam. It broke diplomatic relations with UK on 7 March 1989 giving the explanation that "in the past two centuries Britain has been in the frontline of plots and treachery against Islam and Muslims", It accused the British of sponsoring Rushdie's book to use it as a political and cultural tact on earlier military plots that no longer worked.<ref>Islamic Revolution News Agency, 7 March 1989</ref> It also saw itself as the victor of the controversy, with the European Community countries capitulating under Iranian pressure. "When Europeans saw that their economic interests in Muslim countries could be damaged, they began to correct their position on the issue of the insulting book. Every official started to condemn the book in one way or another. When they realised that Iran's reaction, its breaking of diplomatic relations with London, could also include them, they quickly sent back their ambassadors to Tehran to prevent further Iranian reaction".<ref>''Kayhan Havai'', 18 April 1989</ref>
===Book sales=== [[File:Salman Rushdie, Satanic Verses -1988- illegal Iranian edition.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|Persian [[Samizdat]] edition of [[Salman Rushdie]]'s ''[[The Satanic Verses|Satanic Verses]]'' c.2000]] Although British bookseller [[W.H. Smith]] sold "a mere hundred copies a week of the book in mid-January 1989", it "flew off the shelves" following the fatwa. In America it sold an "unprecedented" five times more copies than the number two book, ''Star'' by [[Danielle Steel]], selling more than 750,000 copies of the book by May 1989. B. Dalton, a bookstore chain that decided not to stock the book for security reasons, changed its mind when it found the book "was selling so fast that even as we tried to stop it, it was flying off the shelves".<ref>Len Riggioi quoted in ''Publishers Weekly'', 10 March 1989</ref><ref>Pipes, 1990, p.200-1</ref> Rushdie earned about $2 million within the first year of the book's publication,<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.205</ref> and the book is Viking's all-time best seller.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alislam.org/books/rushdie/RUSHDIE_Haunted_by_his_unholy_ghosts.pdf |title=RUSHDIE: Haunted by his unholy ghosts |format=PDF |accessdate=27 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204055505/http://www.alislam.org/books/rushdie/RUSHDIE_Haunted_by_his_unholy_ghosts.pdf |archivedate=4 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Rushdie=== The author of the book himself was not killed or injured as many militants wished, but visibly frustrated by a life locked in 24-hour armed guard – alternately defiant against his would-be killers and attempting overtures of reconciliation against the death threat. A week after the death threat, and after his unsuccessful apology to the Iranian government, Rushdie described succumbing to "a curious lethargy, the soporific torpor that overcomes ... while under attack";<ref>Salman Rushdie, "Beginning of a Novelist's Thralldom" ''The Observer'', 26 February 1989</ref> then, a couple of weeks after that, wrote a poem vowing "not to shut up" but "to sing on, in spite of attacks".<ref>6 March 1989 published in ''Granta'', Autumn 1989</ref> But in June, following the death of Khomeini, he asked his supporters "to tone down their criticism of Iran".
His wife, [[Marianne Wiggins]], reported that in the first few months following the fatwa the couple moved 56 times, once every three days. In late July Rushdie separated from Wiggins, "the tension of being at the centre of an international controversy, and the irritations of spending all hours of the day together in seclusion", being too much for their "shaky" relationship.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.203</ref>
Late the next year Rushdie declared, "I want to reclaim my life", and in December signed a declaration "affirming his Islamic faith and calling for Viking-Penguin, the publisher of ''The Satanic Verses'', neither to issue the book in paperback nor to allow it to be translated".<ref name=pipes201>{{Cite news |url=http://www.danielpipes.org/article/201 |title=Rushdie Fails to Move the Zealots |author=Daniel Pipes |work=Los Angeles Times |date=28 December 1990 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070408075454/http://www.danielpipes.org/article/201 |archivedate=8 April 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This also failed to move supporters of the fatwa and by mid-2005 Rushdie was condemning [[Islamic fundamentalism]] as a
<blockquote> ... project of [[tyranny]] and unreason which wishes to freeze a certain view of Islamic culture in time and silence the progressive voices in the Muslim world calling for a free and prosperous future. ... along comes [[9/11]], and now many people say that, in hindsight, the fatwa was the prologue and this is the main event.<ref>{{cite web |author=Shikha Dalmia from the August/September 2005 issue |url=http://www.reason.com/news/show/33120.html |title=The Iconoclast |work=Reason |accessdate=27 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903081731/http://reason.com/news/show/33120.html |archivedate=3 September 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref></blockquote>
A memoir of his years of hiding, titled ''[[Joseph Anton]]'', was published on 18 September 2012. Joseph Anton was Rushdie's secret alias.<ref name="fatwa memoir">{{cite news |work=The Guardian |date=12 April 2012 |title=Salman Rushdie reveals details of fatwa memoir |author=Alison Flood |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/apr/12/salman-rushdie-reveals-fatwa-memoir |accessdate=27 April 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226102636/http://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/apr/12/salman-rushdie-reveals-fatwa-memoir |archivedate=26 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Explanation of different reactions===
====Muslim==== The passionate international rage of Muslims towards the book surprised many Western readers because the book was written in English, not [[Arabic]], [[Urdu]], [[Persian language|Persian]] or other languages for which the majority of mother tongue speakers are Muslims; it was never published or even sold in the countries where most Muslims lived; and was a work of fiction—a demanding, densely written novel unlikely to appeal to the average reader.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.85</ref>
Some of the explanations for the unprecedented rage unleashed against the book were that: *''The Satanic Verses'' was seen as a continuation of the long tradition of anti-Islamic sentiment in Western literature, portraying the core subject matter of the Prophet Muhammad and Islam in a derogatory manner<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/107049639/Mis-Representations-of-Islam-Reading-Salman-Rushdie-s-The-Satanic-Verses-By-Ismail-Isa-Patel-London-1998 Mis/Representations of Islam: Reading Salman Rushdie's The Satanic Verses, By Ismail Isa Patel London 1998] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306152056/https://www.scribd.com/doc/107049639/Mis-Representations-of-Islam-Reading-Salman-Rushdie-s-The-Satanic-Verses-By-Ismail-Isa-Patel-London-1998 |date=6 March 2016 }}</ref> *Rushdie was living in the West and ought to be setting a good example for Islam and not siding "with the Orientalists".<ref>Syed Ali Ashraf, writing in ''Impact International'', 28 October 1988</ref> *The view of many Muslims was that "Rushdie has portrayed the prophet of Islam as a brothel keeper".<ref>ad by the [[Birmingham Central Mosque]] in British newspapers</ref>{{dubious|date=September 2012}} "Rushdie accuses the prophet, particularly Muhammad of being like prostitutes".<ref>Dawud Assad, president of the [[U.S. Council of Masajid]] quoted in ''[[Trenton Times]]'', 21 February 1989</ref> "all who pray are sons of whores"<ref>a young French Muslim quoted in ''Le Nouvel Observateur, 23 March 1989</ref> "The Prophet's wives are portrayed as women of the street, his homes as a public brothel and his companions as bandits".<ref>M. Rafiqul Islam, ''The Rushdie Affair: A Conflict of Rights'' unpublished manuscript, April 1989, p.3</ref> The book, in fact, portrays prostitutes who "had each assumed the identity of one of Mahound's wives".<ref>Salman Rushdie, "The Satanic Verses", Random House, 1988, p. 393</ref> *Belief that fictional elements of the novel were not flights of imagination but lies. Complaints included that it was "neither a critical appraisal nor a piece of historical research",<ref>Mir Husayn Musavi, prime minister of Iran, quoted on Radio Tehran 21 February 1989</ref> that the novel failed to rely on "scientific and logical arguments",<ref>(Muhammad Husayn Fadlallah, Agence France Press, 27 February 1989)</ref> its "lack of scientific, accurate or objective methods of research",<ref>(Shaykh Ahmad Kaftaru, mufti of the Syrian Arab Republic, source: Syrian Arab News Agency, 1 March 1989</ref> "unfounded lies", not being "serious or scientific",<ref>Religious affairs director of Turkish government, Mustafa Sait Yazicioglu, Radio Ankara 14 March 1989</ref> "a total distortion of historical facts",<ref>Sayed M. Syeed, secretary general of the Association of Muslim Social Scientists in the United States, Philadelphia Inquirer, 14 February 1989</ref> being "not at all an objective or scientific opinion".<ref>Libyan ambassador to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights</ref> *Unfamiliarity with the concept of free speech. The belief among many Muslims in or from the Middle East is that every country "has ... laws that prohibits any publications or utterances that tend to ridicule or defame Islam".<ref>editorial in ''The Jordan Times'', 5 March 1989]</ref> It followed that permission to publish a book that ridiculed or defamed Islam showed an anti-Islamic bias in those countries that permit publication. Although not enforced, and abolished completely in 2008, the United Kingdom had [[blasphemy law in the United Kingdom|laws prohibiting blasphemy against the Christian religion.]] *The view of many Muslims that Britain, America and other Western countries are engaged in a [[war on Islam|war against Islam]] and what might on the surface appear to be the product of the imagination of an individual iconoclast author was actually a conspiracy on a national or transnational scale. Then Iranian president [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]], for example, explained the alleged historical roots of the Rushdie book in a broadcast on Radio Tehran:
<blockquote>Whoever is familiar with the history of colonialism and the Islamic world knows that whenever they wanted to get a foothold in a place, the first thing they did in order to clear their paths – whether overtly or covertly – was to undermine the people's genuine Islamic morals.<ref name="Radio Tehran 1990 p.124-5">broadcast Radio Tehran, 7 March 1989 quoted in Pipes, 1990, p.124-5</ref> </blockquote>
and claimed an unnamed British foreign secretary once told the British parliament, "So long as the Qur'an is revered by Muslims, we will not be able to consolidate a foothold among the Muslims".<ref name="Radio Tehran 1990 p.124-5"/>
*A campaign by the international Islamist group [[Jamaat-e-Islami Pakistan|Jamaat-e-Islami]] in retaliation for Rushdie's satire of them in the earlier book ''[[Shame (Rushdie novel)|Shame]]''. In Britain the group was represented by the UK Action Committee on Islamic Affairs".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+:&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false From Fatwa to Jihad: The Rushdie Affair and Its Aftermath By Kenan Malik] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509201749/https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+%3A&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA |date=9 May 2016 }}, chapter one, (no page numbers)</ref> *Among second generation Muslim immigrants in UK and elsewhere, a decline in interest in universalist "white Left" anti-racist/anti-imperialist politics, and rise in [[identity politics]] with its focus on the "defence of values and beliefs" of Muslim identity.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+:&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false From Fatwa to Jihad: The Rushdie Affair and Its Aftermath By Kenan Malik] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509201749/https://books.google.com/books?id=wYkQXO4sEoAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=From+fatwa+to+jihad+%3A&hl=en&ei=yHXdTaG4OKTf0QHB7qTqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA |date=9 May 2016 }}, introduction, part 5, no page numbers</ref> *Based on the book's title, and out of a general ignorance about what it references, a misunderstanding in the part of people in Muslim majority countries, where the book was not available, that led to the belief that the book was a "Satanist" critique of Islam and the Prophet Muhammad.
====Western mainstream==== Despite the passionate intensity of Muslim feeling on the issue no Western government banned ''The Satanic Verses.'' This is primarily because most Western governments explicitly or implicitly allow for freedom of expression, which includes forbidding censorship in the vast majority of cases. Western attitudes regarding freedom of expression differ from those in the Arab world because:
*Westerners are less likely to be shocked by ridicule of religious figures. "Taboo and sacrilege are virtually dead in the West. Blasphemy is an old story and can no longer shock".<ref>Pipes, 1990 p.108</ref> Examples of movies and books that aroused little or no protest in the west despite their blasphemy: [[Joseph Heller]]'s ''[[God Knows (novel)|God Knows]]'', which turned "Biblical stories into pornographic fare";<ref name="Pipes108-118-9">Pipes, 1990 p.108, 118–9</ref> Even ''[[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion]]'', a book that was not only offensive and untrue but arguably very dangerous, having inspired the killing of Jews in Russia and contributed to Nazi ideology, was "freely available in the west".<ref name="Pipes108-118-9"/> *The idea widely accepted among writers that provocation in literature is not a right but is a duty, an important calling: "it is perhaps in the nature of modern art to be offensive ... in this century if we are not willing to risk giving offence, we have no claim to the title of artists".<ref>John Updike, ''The Wall Street Journal'', 10 August 1989</ref> Rushdie himself said: "I had spent my entire life as a writer in opposition, and indeed conceived the writer's role as including the function of antagonist to the state".<ref>Rushdie, Salman, ''Jaguar Smile'', p.50</ref>
The last point also explains why one of the few groups to speak out in Muslim countries against Khomeini and for Rushdie's right to publish his book were other writers.<ref>"The Importance of Being Earnest About Salman Rushdie" by Sadeq al-'Azm, in M.D. Fletcher, ''Reading Rushdie: Perspectives on the Fiction of Salman Rushdie'', Amsterdam, Rodopi B.V., 1994</ref> Nobel prize winners [[Wole Soyinka]] of Nigeria and [[Naguib Mahfouz]] of Egypt, both attacked Khomeini, and both received death threats as a result, with Mahfouz later getting stabbed in the neck by a Muslim fundamentalist.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.148, 175</ref><ref name="guardian2009"/>
Some Western politicians and writers did criticise Rushdie. Former United States president [[Jimmy Carter]], while condemning the threats and [[fatwa]] against Rushdie, stated, "we have tended to promote him and his book with little acknowledgment that it is a direct insult to those millions of Moslems whose sacred beliefs have been violated and are suffering in restrained silence the added embarrassment of the Ayatollah's irresponsibility". He also held that Rushdie must have been aware of the response his book would evoke: "The author, a well-versed analyst of Moslem beliefs, must have anticipated a horrified reaction throughout the Islamic world".<ref>"[[International Herald Tribune]]", 4 July 2007</ref> He saw a need to be "sensitive to the concern and anger" of Muslims and thought severing diplomatic relations with Iran would be an "overreaction".<ref>Jimmy Carter, "Rushdie's Book Is an Insult", ''The New York Times'', 5 March 1989</ref>
Among authors, [[Roald Dahl]] was scathing and called Rushdie's book sensationalist and Rushdie "a dangerous opportunist".<ref name="nyt2007">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/04/arts/04iht-15donadio.6482640.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=Salman Rushdie: Fighting words on a knighthood |author=Rachel Donadio |date=4 July 2007 |work=The New York Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170721200426/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/04/arts/04iht-15donadio.6482640.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |archivedate=21 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[John le Carré]] thought the death sentence to be outrageous, but he also criticised Rushdie's action: "I don't think it is given to any of us to be impertinent to great religions with impunity",<ref name="nyt2007"/> although he later expressed regret over his dispute with Rushdie.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/9671959/Le-Carre-regrets-Rushdie-fatwa-feud.html |title=Le Carré regrets Rushdie fatwa feud |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=12 November 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007224222/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/9671959/Le-Carre-regrets-Rushdie-fatwa-feud.html |archivedate=7 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Rushdie, however, was supported by major bodies in the literary world such as [[PEN International|PEN]] and [[Association of American Publishers]], and prominent figures such as [[Günter Grass]], [[Martin Amis]], [[Saul Bellow]], [[Nadine Gordimer]] and [[Derek Walcott]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/13/books/3d-anniversary-of-edict-against-rushdie.html |title=3d Anniversary of Edict Against Rushdie |date=13 February 1992 |work=The New York Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305145821/http://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/13/books/3d-anniversary-of-edict-against-rushdie.html |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Another major supporter of Rushdie, [[Christopher Hitchens]], said that the fatwa persuaded him that Islamic fundamentalism was an urgent menace, and later wrote ''[[God Is Not Great]]'', a polemic against religion.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/12/16/143830372/for-hitchens-in-life-and-death-an-unaware-cosmos |title=For Hitchens, In Life And Death, An Unaware Cosmos |author=Barbara Bradley Hagerty |date=16 December 2011 |publisher=NPR |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006093757/http://www.npr.org/2011/12/16/143830372/for-hitchens-in-life-and-death-an-unaware-cosmos |archivedate=6 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The affair however led to greater caution and some degree of self-censorship when dealing with Islamic issues in the literary and other creative arts.<ref name="guardian2009">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jan/11/salman-rushdie-satanic-verses |title=How one book ignited a culture war |author=Andrew Anthony |work=The Observer |date=11 January 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106013924/https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jan/11/salman-rushdie-satanic-verses |archivedate=6 January 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Western religious figures==== Many religious figures in the United States and United Kingdom shared the aversion to blasphemy of pious Muslims (if not as intensely) and did not defend Rushdie like their secular compatriots. The [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Robert Runcie]], demanded that the government expand the [[blasphemy law in the United Kingdom|Blasphemy Act]] to cover other religions, including Islam.<ref name="Longworth">{{Cite news|title=Britain's blasphemy laws getting renewed attention |first=R.C. |last=Longworth |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8eUPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NowDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6740,4165272 |newspaper=[[The Free Lance–Star]] |location=Fredericksburg, Virginia |date=11 March 1989 |page=5 |accessdate=16 November 2009}}</ref>
Michael Walzer wrote that the response revealed an evolution of the meaning of blasphemy; it moved away from a crime against God and toward something more temporal.
<blockquote>Today we are concerned for our pain and sometimes, for other people's. Blasphemy has become an offence against the faithful – in much the same way as pornography is an offence against the innocent and the virtuous. Given this meaning, blasphemy is an ecumenical crime and so it is not surprising ... that Christians and Jews should join Muslims in calling Salman Rushdie's [book] a blasphemous book.<ref>Michael Walzer, "The Sins of Salman", ''The New Republic'', 10 April 1989</ref></blockquote>
Some [[rabbis]], such as [[Immanuel Jakobovits]], [[chief rabbi]] of the United Hebrew Congregations of the Commonwealth, opposed the book's publication.<ref>''The Times'', 4 March 1989</ref>
==Reception timeline==

[[Srinivas Aravamudan]].Diacritics, Vol. 19, No. 2 (Summer, 1989), pp. 3–20</ref><ref>Postmodernist Perceptions of Islam: Observing the Observer. Akbar S. Ahmed. ''The Times of India''. 13 October 1988.</ref> In 1993 Syed Shahabuddin tried unsuccessfully to ban another book ([[Ram Swarup]]'s ''Hindu View of Christianity and Islam'').<ref>Arun Shourie: How should we respond? In The Observer of Business and Politics, New Delhi, 26 November 1993, also published in many other Indian newspapers and periodicals and reprinted in Sita Ram Goel (ed.): Freedom of Expression – Secular Theocracy Versus Liberal Democracy, 1998 {{ISBN|81-85990-55-7}}. {{cite web |url=http://voiceofdharma.com/books/foe/ch13.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185013/http://voiceofdharma.com/books/foe/ch13.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>Statement by Indian intellectuals on Syed Shahabuddin's attempt to make the authorities impose a ban on the book Hindu View of Christianity and Islam by Ram Swarup, Delhi, 18 November. Reprinted in Sita Ram Goel (ed.): Freedom of Expression – Secular Theocracy Versus Liberal Democracy 1998 {{ISBN|81-85990-55-7}} {{cite web |url=http://voiceofdharma.com/books/foe/ch13.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185013/http://voiceofdharma.com/books/foe/ch13.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *October 1988: Death threats against Rushdie compel him to cancel trips and sometimes take a bodyguard. Letter writing campaign to Viking Press in America brings "tens of thousands of menacing letters".<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.22</ref> *20 October 1988: Union of Muslim Organisations of the UK writes the British government pressing for a ban of ''The Satanic Verse'' on grounds of blasphemy.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.21</ref> *21 November 1988: Grand sheik of Egypt Al-Azhar calls on Islamic organisations in Britain to take legal action to prevent the novel's distribution *24 November 1988: The novel is banned in South Africa and Pakistan; bans follow within weeks in [[Saudi Arabia]], Egypt, [[Somalia]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Sudan]], [[Malaysia]], Indonesia, and [[Qatar]]. *2 December 1988: First book burning of ''The Satanic Verses'' in UK. 7000 Muslims attend rally burning the book in Bolton,<ref name="Pipes23">Pipes, 1990, p.23</ref> though the event is barely noticed by the media.<ref>Malik, Kenan. ''From Fatwa to Jihad: The Rushdie Affair and Its Aftermath''. Melville House (2010): p. 4</ref>
===1989=== *14 January 1989: A copy of the book is burned in Bradford. Extensive media coverage and debate. Some support from non-Muslims.<ref name="Pipes23"/> *January 1989: [[Islamic Defense Council]] demands that [[Penguin Books]] apologise, withdraw the novel, destroy any extant copies, and never reprint it. *February 1989: The first copies of the United States edition appear in bookstores, along with book reviews in the US press. *12 February 1989: Six people are killed and 100 injured when 10,000 attack the American Cultural Center in [[Islamabad, Pakistan]] protesting against Rushdie and his book.<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.25</ref> *13 February 1989: One person is killed and over 100 injured in anti-Rushdie riots in Srinagar, [[Jammu and Kashmir]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Freedom of Information and Expression in India|url=http://www.pucl.org/from-archives/Media/freedom.htm|date=October 1990|publisher=Article 19|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020820035249/http://pucl.org/from-archives/Media/freedom.htm|archivedate=20 August 2002|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>Pipes, 1990, p.26</ref> *14 February 1989: [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini]] of [[Iran]] issues a fatwa calling on all Muslims to execute all those involved in the publication of the novel; the 15 [[Khordad]] Foundation, an Iranian religious foundation or [[bonyad]], offers a reward of $US1 million or 200 million rials for the murder of Rushdie, $3 million if done by an Iranian. *16 February 1989: Various armed Islamist groups, such as Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corp and Hezbollah of Lebanon, express their enthusiasm to "carry out the Imam's decree".<ref>Pipes, 1990, p.28-9</ref> Rushdie enters the protection programme of the British government. The bounty on his head is raised to $6 million.<ref name="month-rushdies"/> *17 February 1989: Iranian president [[Ali Khamenei]] says Rushdie could be pardoned if he apologises.<ref>Article "Iran suggests an apology could save life of Rushdie; Rushdie controversy". Dalton, [[Barnes & Noble]], [[Waldenbooks]], and Coles Book Stores say that they will no longer sell the book.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Furor Over 'Satanic Verses' Rises As 2 More Book Chains Halt Sales|author=Edwin McDowell|date=18 February 1989|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/04/18/specials/rushdie-furor.html|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306115810/http://www.nytimes.com/books/99/04/18/specials/rushdie-furor.html|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *18 February 1989: Rushdie apologizes as President Khamenei suggested; initially, [[IRNA]] (the official Iranian news agency) says Rushdie's statement "is generally seen as sufficient enough to warrant his pardon".<ref>Article "Iranians in confusion after Rushdie apologizes; Rushdie controversy". The Sunday Times (London, England), 19 February 1989, accessed via Infotrac.</ref> *19 February 1989: Ayatollah Khomeini issues edict saying no apology or contrition by Rushdie could lift his death sentence. *22 February 1989: The novel is published in the USA; major bookstore chains [[Barnes & Noble]] and [[Waldenbooks]], under threat, remove the novel from one-third of the nation's bookstores. *24 February 1989: Twelve people die and 40 are wounded when a large anti-Rushdie riot in Bombay, [[Maharashtra]], India starts to cause considerable property damage and police open fire.<ref>{{Cite book|title=World Almanac and Book of Facts, 1990|author=Mark S. Hoffman|publisher=World Almanac Books|isbn=0-88687-559-5}}</ref> *28 February 1989: Bookstores, including Cody's and [[Waldenbooks]] in [[Berkeley, California]], USA, are firebombed for selling the novel.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Firebombs Damage 2 Berkeley Book Shops : Another Hits N.Y. Newspaper; Bush Warns Against Violent Protests Over Rushdie Novel|author1=Kevin Roderick|author2=John J. Goldman|lastauthoramp=yes|date=1 March 1989|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-03-01/news/mn-574_1_berkeley-book|work=Los Angeles Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130328071641/http://articles.latimes.com/1989-03-01/news/mn-574_1_berkeley-book|archivedate=28 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *28 February 1989: [[1989 firebombing of the Riverdale Press]]: The offices of the ''[[Riverdale Press]]'', a weekly newspaper in [[the Bronx]], is destroyed by firebombs. A caller to 911 says the bombing was in retaliation for an editorial defending the right to read the novel and criticising the chain stores that stopped selling it.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Two Rabbis Find They're Separated Only by Doctrine|author=Samuel G. Freedman|date=30 May 2009|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/30/us/30religion.html|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151108093908/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/30/us/30religion.html|archivedate=8 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *7 March 1989: Iran breaks diplomatic [[Iran–United Kingdom relations|relations]] with Britain. *March 1989: Independent book stores including Cody's in [[Berkeley, California]], United States and Powell's in [[Portland, Oregon]], United States continue to sell the book.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ross|first=Andy|title=Remembering the Rushdie Affair|url=http://andyrossagency.wordpress.com/2009/11/18/remembering-the-rushdie-affair/|work=Ask the Agent: Night Thoughts about Books and Publishing|publisher=wordpress.com|accessdate=6 October 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904095518/http://andyrossagency.wordpress.com/2009/11/18/remembering-the-rushdie-affair/|archivedate=4 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *March 1989: The [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] calls on its 46 member governments to prohibit the novel. The Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar sets the punishment for possession of the book as three years in prison and a fine of $2,500; in Malaysia, three years in prison and a fine of $7,400; in Indonesia, a month in prison or a fine. The only nation with a predominantly Muslim population where the novel remains legal is Turkey. Several nations with large Muslim minorities, including Papua New Guinea, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Kenya, Tanzania, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, also impose penalties for possessing the novel. *May 1989: Popular musician Yusuf Islam (formerly known as [[Cat Stevens]]) indicates his support for the fatwa and states during a British television documentary, according to the ''New York Times'', that if Rushdie shows up at his door, he "might ring somebody who might do more damage to him than he would like... I'd try to phone the Ayatollah Khomeini and tell him exactly where this man is".<ref>{{Cite news|last =R. Whitney|first =Craig|title =Cat Stevens Gives Support To Call for Death of Rushdie|work =The New York Times|date =23 May 1989|url =https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/04/18/specials/rushdie-cat.html|accessdate =22 January 2006|deadurl =no|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090310180836/http://www.nytimes.com/books/99/04/18/specials/rushdie-cat.html|archivedate =10 March 2009|df =dmy-all}}</ref> Yusuf Islam later denied giving support to the fatwa.
